items.content_html:
Summary

Compat data about where path() can be used is outdated and inconsistent with other MDN pages, especially clip-path.

This PR aims to fix this and adds an additional row for every place where path() could or could not be used.

Test results and supporting details

I tested that support for path in clip-path was indeed present for the three major browsers, see my comment in #20004.

There is a small mismatch in two version numbers with css.properties.offset-path vs css.types.basic-shape.path:

  • offset-path with path() added in firefox version 72 vs 63
  • offset-path with path() added in chrome version 64 vs 46

I haven't been able to find the truth.

Git logs for chrome 64 contain some mentions of offset-path and path(), but it seems only animation of these was implemented in that release.
Git logs for chrome 46 make no mention of offset-path at all.

Related issues

Fixes #20004, #15961
items.title: Fix incorrect information about path()

items.content_html:
This PR is a breakdown list of all the changes created by https://mdn-bcd-collector.gooborg.com. This PR will be continuously updated, both on every new collector release and as needed.

Current results: collector v9.4.0, generated June 9, 2023
items.title: mdn-bcd-collector v9.4.0 breakdown (2023-06-09)

items.content_html: This PR removes the RTCRtpEncodingParameters API from BCD. This feature is a type (ex. a dictionary, enum, mixin, constant or WebIDL typedef) that we have explicitly stated not to document separately from the feature(s) that depend on it, as they are virtually invisible to the end developer.
items.title: Remove RTCRtpEncodingParameters API from BCD

items.content_html: This PR removes the RTCRtpContributingSource API from BCD. This feature is a type (ex. a dictionary, enum, mixin, constant or WebIDL typedef) that we have explicitly stated not to document separately from the feature(s) that depend on it, as they are virtually invisible to the end developer.
items.title: Remove RTCRtpContributingSource API from BCD

items.content_html:
This PR removes the RTCIceServer API from BCD. This feature is a type (ex. a dictionary, enum, mixin, constant or WebIDL typedef) that we have explicitly stated not to document separately from the feature(s) that depend on it, as they are virtually invisible to the end developer.

Additional Notes: I'd love for someone to take on the content changes if possible, but if nobody is interested I'd be happy to give the content updates a shot!
items.title: Remove RTCIceServer API from BCD

items.content_html:
Summary

This PR adds a compatibility and spec's for the SVG shape-subtract attribute. A follow up to my PR adding this item to the MDN docs.

First time contributor here, please feel free to let me know if there was something I could've done better.

Test results and supporting details

In my testing for compatibility I was unable to find a browser that supported this feature, even though it is on the standards track.

Testing as Not Supported in:

  • Chrome: 110.0.581.178
  • Firefox: 110.0.1
  • Opera: 95.0.4635.46
  • Edge: 110.0.1587.63

But there are some resources that indicate it could be a WIP:

  • Chromium Bug report asking for this feature support
  • Chromium Test Cases for this Feature
  • Firefox Test Cases for this Feature

Also if helpful, the specification.

Related issues

Supplies my companion PR mdn/content#25077 with it's compatibility table and specification link.
items.title: Add `shape-subtract` compatibility data

items.content_html:
Summary

Fixes/improves the support data for the CSS mask shorthand property for Firefox and Safari.

  • Firefox: marked the Firefox 2 entry as partial support; added an entry with the version which added support for CSS Masking Module Level 1.
  • Safari: added an entry for Safari 15.4, which shipped the unprefixed mask property.

Test results and supporting details

My rationale was that the support data should be a rough match for “does this browser support the CSS Masking Level 1: Positioned Masks feature?”

In the case of Firefox, relevant release notes are:

  • Firefox 2 (the version that is in the current data): no mentions of masks.
  • Firefox 10: mention of a change to the color space used for SVG masks.
  • Firefox 47: adds CSS Mask Image support in Nightly.
  • Firefox 53: ships CSS Masks by default.

I could not find a description of what the mask property did in Firefox 2+ and before Firefox 53. My memory tells me that it supported SVG masks (as mask: url(image.svg)) so I wrote that down in the notes. It's also far enough from the CSS Masking Module definition of mask to warrant a “partial implementation” flag.

The notes for Firefox 2+ had an extract from the Firefox 10 release notes about sRGB vs Linear RGB and Firefox aligning with the SVG 1.1 spec, which IMHO is a minute implementation detail that may not be worth mentioning.

For Safari, it shipped the unprefixed mask property in Safari 15.4 (release notes).

Retiring WebKit prefixes

In an ongoing effort to reduce dependency on prefixes, WebKit newly supports several CSS properties and values that were only previous available in an earlier form. The prefixed versions will still work, now aliased to the unprefixed versions. Safari 15.4 added support for:

  • appearance, including appearance: auto
  • mask, along with the long-hand forms mask-image, mask-size, mask-repeat-x, mask-repeat-y, mask-origin
  • backface-visibility
  • text-combine-upright
  • print-color-adjust
  • match-parent CSS value for the text-align property
items.title: Fix support data for the CSS mask shorthand property
